658534255.name: una de las playas mas limpias de la zona
658534255.author: a TripAdvisor user
658534255.reviewBody: los alimentos sonlo mejor todo esta en su punto y como deberia de ser todo frescoy acompa\u00f1ado de una esquicita ensalda

665016967.name: Highly recommended
665016967.author: a TripAdvisor user
665016967.reviewBody: This is a delightful stop......expected a planetarium show, but got much more. Outside the building were costumed performers. If I may regress, on the pathway to the building stood the performers, some holding incense and another blowing smoke at us. Then we sat on chairs to watch a performance about Mayan culture..........very interesting.\nThen we went inside the building to watch the planetarium show of what the skies would have been like during the Mayan era and how it affected their culture. The seats in the theater do recline and there are a few steps to get to the seats.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Paseo de los Cerritos s/n Col.Los Cerritos

584597098.name: Nice planetarium and show
584597098.author: a TripAdvisor user
584597098.reviewBody: This location was opened for us on a Sunday when our cruise ship excursion arrived on a previously unscheduled date.  Before entering the building, we were treated to a cultural dance performance by a local group of arts students, including the jaguar king.  This was very entertaining.  The planetarium was excellent and featured a description of the uses to which Mayan temples and related structures were used to chart the locations and movements of the planets and stars.  This presentation added a lot to our information.  Afterwards, locals offered arts and crafts in the lobby at outstandingly low prices.  The location also was well air-conditioned.  A photographic display in the lobby showed the historical development of the town of Tapachula. All in all a wonderful opportunity.  Recommended if you are in Tapachula.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Paseo de los Cerritos s/n Col.Los Cerritos

579730188.name: A hit!
579730188.author: a TripAdvisor user
579730188.reviewBody: Sometimes cruise shore excursions are hit or miss.  This was a hit!  We were treated to colorful ceremonial Mayan dances, then some lovely art, and finally the planetarium show of the Mayan Cosmos.  The reclining seats are so comfortablie one could easily fall asleep.  Don\'t, as you\'d miss a very interesting an educational presentation that is well worth the time and money.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Paseo de los Cerritos s/n Col.Los Cerritos

485820278.name: Unusual Dome Projection!
485820278.author: a TripAdvisor user
485820278.reviewBody: Before going inside the planetarium we were given a cultural presentation at the entrance of the building. It was a popular display  of what Mayan beliefs and sacrifices might have been. We spent around thirty minutes stargazing inside the planetarium. The dome projection is the main attraction of this venue.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Paseo de los Cerritos s/n Col.Los Cerritos

482461569.name: Nice For a Short Stop
482461569.author: a TripAdvisor user
482461569.reviewBody: Saw the planetarium show on Mayan astrology and a nice Mayan dance ritual. Some nice things to buy. Nice and cool inside on a hot and humid afternoon.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Paseo de los Cerritos s/n Col.Los Cerritos

473925758.name: Not With Th Ship, But Got to See the Show!
473925758.author: a TripAdvisor user
473925758.reviewBody: We were on the Panama Canal Cruise and had taken a shuttle to Tapachula for the day knowing that we were going to get a taxi over to th planetarium. When we arrived we were informed that if we wanted to wait for the cruise ship tour we could see the Mayan Ceremonial Dance Show and then pay 50 pesos each to see the show in the planetarium.   Sounded like a great plan to us.   We informed our driver and he was in agreement.  The Mayan show was fabulous and the show in the planetarium was very informative.  Keep in mind that you are not in the US and the the show is rather simple compared to what you would see at home.  But at the same time is full of great information.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Paseo de los Cerritos s/n Col.Los Cerritos

372949061.name: Nice half day activity
372949061.author: a TripAdvisor user
372949061.reviewBody: I enjoyed my visit to the planetrium. The staff were very accommodating and informative.  I wasn\'t with a cruise ship and the viewing of the Mayans and celestial bodies was not scheduled. However after the scheduled projection, they put that one on for me as well. In particular I loved the photography exhibition of earlier days in Tapachula. The permanent pieces of Mayan flywire art by Thomas E. Carlos de la Cerda are very moving.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Paseo de los Cerritos s/n Col.Los Cerritos

330667911.name: Shore Excursion from Puerto Chiapas, Mexico
330667911.author: a TripAdvisor user
330667911.reviewBody: After a visit to the Izapa ruins we headed to the Tapachula Planetarium.  Here we were introduced to Mayan Cosmology and enjoyed a Mayan folkloric performance. \nThe seats in the planetarium recline to a near lie flat position.  Then the lights slowly dim and are finally turned off, leaving you in total blackness.  Next you will enjoy the 15 minute audio-visual presentation on the stars and how they were used by the Mayans in building their cities and temples.   At the conclusion of the presentation, allow your eyes to adjust to the light and then head outside for a traditional Mayan Leopard Warrior dance.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Paseo de los Cerritos s/n Col.Los Cerritos

272797140.name: Show and some shopping....
272797140.author: a TripAdvisor user
272797140.reviewBody: Here on a cruise ship stop.  Started with a wonderful dance/ceremony outside on the plaza,  appreciated they had chairs for us.  Was very interesting.  Inside we saw a show about the stars and Mayan history,  was also interesting.  Some shopping at little stands.  Clean, very nice building. In an interesting area,  looks like it was  an \'educational\' area.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Paseo de los Cerritos s/n Col.Los Cerritos

257890363.name: Its All in the Stars
257890363.author: a TripAdvisor user
257890363.reviewBody: Interesting to learn how the stars aligned during the time of the building of Izapa. The displays outside the planetarium were amazing -- especially the 3-dimensional paintings.  The "welcome" dance outside the building was also lovely.  The costumes were so colorful.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Paseo de los Cerritos s/n Col.Los Cerritos

244713743.name: Planetarium Tapachula Chiapas Mexico
244713743.author: a TripAdvisor user
244713743.reviewBody: We visited the Planetarium in Tapachula during a cruise stop in Puerto Chiapas during our cruise through the Panama Canal from Long Beach to Miami.      We were on the "Chiapas through the ages" tour from the NCL Star.  It was about a 35 minute ride from the port.\n\nThe planetarium is fairly new and has several exhibits about the people of the area.  We watched a presentation on the stars and how they were used by the Mayans in building their cities and temples.  After the presentation, we were treated to a ceremonial dance by a Mayan Leopard Warrior and his assistants.  Outside of the planetarium, there is are a few souvenir stands and the prices are fairly reasonable.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Paseo de los Cerritos s/n Col.Los Cerritos

658534393.name: lugar agradable para estar en familia
658534393.author: a TripAdvisor user
658534393.reviewBody: las fuentes el agua que sale desde abajo es una atraccion para los chiquillos y para los grandes la bonita marimba

address.streetAddress: Av. Central Sur, s/n Tapachula de Córdova and Ordoñez

665025359.name: Gathering place
665025359.author: a TripAdvisor user
665025359.reviewBody: As in most towns in Mexico there are plazas. The plazas are gathering places, some fancy, some simple......most with some activity going on. \nDepending on the day, the plaza can be crowded or not.......on the day we were there it was not overly crowded. \nI found this plaza to be middle of the road, not grand but not plain either. Surrounding the plaza are business, city hall, a church and a museum. The roads surrounding the plaza are very narrow and very busy, so take that into consideration if driving in that area.

607182303.name: Third World Park
607182303.author: a TripAdvisor user
607182303.reviewBody: For the hinterlands of Mexico this may be an OK park but to a typical world traveler it is nothing more than a poorly kept and undistinguished little park.  City Hall across the street is dirty and full of locals loitering around. The church is spartan but, at least clean.   A more interesting Catholic church on the southern outskirt of town has  at least a more visually interesting exterior

584598439.name: Central park crowded with vendors on a Sunday
584598439.author: a TripAdvisor user
584598439.reviewBody: First visited this park in 1963. Quite a change in the intervening years!  On the Sunday when our cruise ship was in port, there were many people and a host of local vendors, selling miscellaneous items to other locals.  The park is convenient to the adjacent city hall where a nice mural (see photo) is featured.  Also adjacent is the local Catholic cathedral.  If you are in Tapachula, you will certainly visit this park.

579732185.name: Perhaps another time?
579732185.author: a TripAdvisor user
579732185.reviewBody: This might be an enjoyable park any day other than December 26 when it was overcrowded with tourists, locals, protestors, and vendors.  It had all the elements: palms, a gazebo, fountains, and flowers, but it was chaotic and traffic was a nightmare.  It was the worst stop on our 19-day Panama Canal cruise. Too bad we saw it at its worst.

485823473.name: Central Meeting Point at Tapachula
485823473.author: a TripAdvisor user
485823473.reviewBody: We went to M. Hidalgo Central Park and the water fountains were spectacular. From this site, the tourist guide showed us the Catholic Church which building size was reduced when the President was non-Catholic. Next to this park are shops, restaurants, the municipal government and other landmarks of the city.\n

481727651.name: Park that tries
481727651.author: a TripAdvisor user
481727651.reviewBody: This park is quite pleasant and their is a very note-able attempt to beautify the park.  The church is plain but welcoming.  There are washrooms in the City Hall at the head of the park.  Handicraft vendors on one side and shoe shine on the other.  There is some shade.  The grounds are not dirty, however, bits of garbage are everywhere.  Their was a police presence.  Ask for directions, locals are very friendly.

473926376.name: Nice Plaza
473926376.author: a TripAdvisor user
473926376.reviewBody: This is not the most beautiful plaza that we have seen in a Mexican City.  But this is the most beautiful in Tapachula and should be appreciated for what it is.  Lots of locals, shops and restaurants.  Be sure and go into th church and the city hall.  Wonder off of the square and see the market, other shops and restaurants.  We were there on a Saturday and it was extremely busy and hot, but it is worth the ten dollar round trip from the cruise terminal.

439995599.name: Part of Puerto Chiapas Cruise Terminal Tour
439995599.author: a TripAdvisor user
439995599.reviewBody: We went to the Tapachula City Center as part of the tour offered at the Puerto Chiapas Cruise Terminal.  It also covered the Izapa Ruins and a chocolate making demonstration.\n\nThe city square is very similar to a lot of other Mexican City Squares.  It has lovely flowers and places to sit.  Our tour guide explained the various types of the buildings that surround the square.  I can see why locals like to spend time here.

398185634.name: Tapachula\'s central park
398185634.author: a TripAdvisor user
398185634.reviewBody: This place is Tapachula downtowns, you can see all around commercial places, boutiques, restaurants, a catholic church, local government, there are many people, children, etc.

380493586.name: Very ordinary
380493586.author: a TripAdvisor user
380493586.reviewBody: The only thing in town apart from stalls selling rubbish to the tourists.  The museum which is located in an old building had promise but it was closed and had been vacated for later restoration.  A dump of a place.  The town hall was the location for a vocal demonstration with a fire burning in the central courtyard.  The food was very ordinary and we could not wait to catch the bus back to the cruise ship

374633963.name: The most iconic place in whole town
374633963.author: a TripAdvisor user
374633963.reviewBody: This is the oldest park for families in the town it was very popular in the past but now is more visited for people who came from Guatemala, but is in the downtown area so you could always visit and have a plenty of choices to have a great dinner around. The weather is always hot here but in the night is more pleasant,  if you are lucky you can listen some Marimba playing live, wich is the most popular instrument in the state. Oh, and don\'t forget to visit the museum wich is next to the old government building.

611036693.name: Un lugar lindo pero le falta promoci\u00f3n
611036693.author: a TripAdvisor user
611036693.reviewBody: Sin duda a lo largo de la costa Chiapaneca hay playas muy lindas que no son comerciales dado que es mar abierto y no hay infraestructura tur\u00edstica, sin embargo es un lugar muy lindo para visitar y disfrutar de manera diferente nuestras playas.

607449594.name: nuevo malec\u00f3n!!
607449594.author: a TripAdvisor user
607449594.reviewBody: El nuevo malec\u00f3n le esta dando mayor impulso a la zona, hay buenos restaurantes donde comer y disfrutar de un tiempo con los amigos y la familia

665028798.name: Interesting
665028798.author: a TripAdvisor user
665028798.reviewBody: This is a quaint in Tapachula. It is situated next to the plaza on the same street as the Museo Arqueologic del Sosonusco. Also in the area is the city hall.\nThe church itself is on the simple side inside. On the front of the building outside it is rustic but interesting. On either side of the building are park like areas. \nThere is enough in this area to keep you busy for awhile.

643388463.name: Un momento para relajarte.....
643388463.author: a TripAdvisor user
643388463.reviewBody: Un buen lugar para compra contando con franquicias exclusivas dentro y fuera de uno de los principales centros reconocidos, como f\u00e1bricas de Francia, al igual que pr\u00e1cticamente los due\u00f1os y/o fundadores de la misma como es Chedrahui. Estacionamiento de 2 niveles y elevador, \u00fatil en caso de personas con capacidades diferentes. Sin duda un lugar para ir de Shoping, y un buen lugar para visitar y pasar el tiempo. Feliz a\u00f1o.

672602840.name: Cuando la naturaleza se impone....
672602840.author: a TripAdvisor user
672602840.reviewBody: Parte de la naturaleza, y como tal hermoso con tramos con excepciones debido ala contaminaci\u00f3n, esto aunado al hacen amiento II regular vuelve lo natural en un punto rojo a lo largo del mismo, sin embargo la naturaleza cobra la factura, esperemos tengamos conciencia y no vuelva a ocurrir lo de hace unos a\u00f1os, disfrutemos lo que la naturaleza nos regala y alimente os las bellezas naturales con cuidados, protecci\u00f3n y dar libre acceso a todo lo bueno que es natural.

649963115.name: Beautiful old church
649963115.author: a TripAdvisor user
649963115.reviewBody: We loved this church and town. It is close to ruins and we paid 40 pesos for motorcycle \ud83c\udfcd taxi to take us to ruins.  Well worth the two stops

607186760.name: Interesting Church Architecture
607186760.author: a TripAdvisor user
607186760.reviewBody: From a distance it almost looks like a Russian Orthodox Church. It is not until you get into the grounds and look more closely that you realize that this is a Catholic Church.    The church and grounds are reasonably well maintained.  Worth a stop if you are in the area.

454353496.name: A very old church but maintained
454353496.author: a TripAdvisor user
454353496.reviewBody: Located in small town of , it is Tapachula a very interesting old church. It was founded by the Spanish.It still maintains it original agriculturee , paint, artifacts altar and seating. Only two itemjs have been replaced, one beiing a ceiling beam and a door structure. The rest is original. It is located about a half black fromthe central plaza. We were fortunate to be there when the farmer\'s market was in operation. That was interesting  with the different agriculture items for sale with their unique diswplay, using local leaves to highlight items. Also on the same dame, it was "tourist" day, and the plaza was blocked off for traffic as there were busses in town. A highlight was the demonstration of how they make cocoa  starting with the cocoa bean and the different steps to the final product. Tasting was given  on the finished product. There are also vendors in the plaza selling cocoa and other interesting local items. This is a definite stop and it is best to include it on a visit to Izapas Mayan Ruins on the wasy

420801693.name: Beautiful, peaceful, unusual
420801693.author: a TripAdvisor user
420801693.reviewBody: One of the most interesting churches I\'ve seen. Certainly a different architectural style than the Spanish colonial churches normally found in Mexico. Lovely gardens to walk through, although small. The fountains weren\'t working when I was there but I\'m sure they would be very pretty. \nTook me less than an hour to walk through the gardens, peek in the church (wish I had the nerve to go in further, it looked beautiful), and take some pictures.\nIt is a bit off the beaten track. I took a taxi here and it cost me 40 pesos from the Miguel Hidalgo plaza.

650947880.name: First visit to Chiapas
650947880.author: a TripAdvisor user
650947880.reviewBody: We have had three individual tours with Angel, what a fantastic, informative & humorous man he is. As we do not speak Spanish it was imperative we had a bilingual guide which Angel is. He was always punctual and accommodated our whims where possible. The visit to Casa Maya is a must for all chocolate lovers, "Cheppy" - The Manager also has a wicked sense of humour and really made our visit very special. Angel is 6ft 5ins and as we found "size really does matter"

656891775.name: Una experiencia \u00fanica
656891775.author: a TripAdvisor user
656891775.reviewBody: Es la mejor opci\u00f3n para conocer el bello estado de Chiapas \ud83d\ude0d. Todas las veces que he tenido oportunidad de visitar Chiapas, Vb Tours ha sido por mucho la mejor agencia. Todos sus Tours tiene un encanto \u00fanico y lo mejor es que te comparten historias, costumbres y cultura de cada lugar. 100% recomendable, son los mejores \ud83d\ude0a\ud83d\ude0b

656891676.name: Gran viaje
656891676.author: a TripAdvisor user
656891676.reviewBody: Fue una excelente experiencia, la atenci\u00f3n fue de lo mejor y visitamos diferentes lugares a los alrededores de Tapachula, con una buena explicaci\u00f3n en cada recorrido, que es algo que valoro mucho en cada viaje.\n\nMuchas gracias VbTours, sin duda 100% recomendados!

665013661.name: Interesting
665013661.author: a TripAdvisor user
665013661.reviewBody:
This was part of a ships excursion. We had an English speaking guide to explain the history of the ruins and area. So if you want to know the most  about this area, it would be best to hire a guide.
The area that you do see isn't that big, but as the guide explained, the site is much larger; but being where it is at, we can't get to it. Yes he explained why and geographically it would be hard to get to the rest of the site.
As stated in other reviews, this is a old Mayan site, so no tall pyramids, no intricate carvings, no interesting buildings. Still it has much history to it and worth seeing.
It is easy to walk around the grounds, but there are no pathways; so the ground can be uneven. Because of that, I would say if you have mobility issues; take into consideration that there are no sidewalks or other smooth pathways.

659977399.name: Authentic early Mayan ruin
659977399.author: a TripAdvisor user
659977399.reviewBody: We visited the ruins on a cruise ship excursion. It is about a 45-minute ride from the cruise port. The ruins are low to the ground, very well preserved and maintained. This is a very early Mayan ruin, so you don\'t see the towering ruins you do an other Mayan sites. The guide we had was very knowledgeable about everything that had happened in this area.  The ground is pretty accessible, but you would have to be walking. It is a little uneven in spots, but I had no problem walking among the ruins.

650948318.name: Arranged tour
650948318.author: a TripAdvisor user
650948318.reviewBody: As we don\'t speak Spanish it was important to have our guide from Nativo Tours. The ruins are quite small but very worth a visit and a history lesson to understand their significance.

649770925.name: 500BC Awesome Ruins
649770925.author: a TripAdvisor user
649770925.reviewBody: 20 minutes from town 200 by taxi well worth the time.  Takes 45 minutes to view and we got collective taxi back 40 pesos. We also saw church further down road at same time

641358945.name: Original and interesting but small sight and not so well preserved
641358945.author: a TripAdvisor user
641358945.reviewBody: The ruins are original in that they have some pillars with spherical stones at the top, a unique feature within Maya culture. It\'s possible to buy a booklet with the explanation for 100 pesos, else than that information is quiet limited. As there are very few visitors it\'s possible to enjoy the visit of the three sights at your own pace, enjoying the nature around.. its posible to see that a couple of hills around should be other pyramids which still need to be uncovered.\nNot suitable for elder or people with disabilities. Good for adults and kids.

584597562.name: Early location of Mayan empire
584597562.author: a TripAdvisor user
584597562.reviewBody: These ruins are fairly simple in the areas presently open to the public, compared to those found in later sites of the "classic" period.  There is little shade and it is recommended that you bring an umbrella and perhaps a battery operated fan.  Worth a visit to check this off the list of Mayan sites in Mexico and central America.

579728110.name: Interesting and very well maintained!
579728110.author: a TripAdvisor user
579728110.reviewBody: We chose this excursion during our Panama Canal cruise and felt it was very worthwhile.  Fortunately it wasn\'t hot that day. I always do my own research when we travel, so we left the group and toured the ruins on our own.  We were impressed how clean and well maintained it is.  Although there are no tall ruins, some are large.  The site stretches out to about a mile, but the main ruins are near the road for easy access.  They include bases of cobbled pyramids, sculptured plazas, ceremonial platforms, and stone- carved monuments that were abandoned around 1200 BC.  It is believed to be the site where the sacred Mayan calendar was born.  A hat, sunscreen, and insect repellant are essential.

576124663.name: Nice history but not spectacular
576124663.author: a TripAdvisor user
576124663.reviewBody: Interesting piece of local history but a little underwhelming. well maintained and good signage on items of interest

573352749.name: I visited Puerto Chiapas ONLY
573352749.author: a TripAdvisor user
573352749.reviewBody: I could not find any where else to do a write up...so I am putting it here.  I came on a cruise ship HA Maasdam in April.  It was quite HOT.  All I did was walk to the little visitors center at the port.  It had dancers  and musicians and a handful of shops.  It is all open air (read that HOT).  There is a small museum of Mayan items.  The items for sale included some cute hand painted animals carvings.  I bought a rabbit that was 3" tall in lavender for  $22.  Quite expensive, but the details were impressive and very different than my other Oaxacan  animals.  I collect rabbits, so it was worth it!

558105111.name: an interesting & historically significant site
558105111.author: a TripAdvisor user
558105111.reviewBody: Izapa (the place of the river of salt) was occupied from the middle prelatic thru the early postclassic (1500 BC to 1200 AD) reached it\'s peak between 850 and 150 BC.  The site covers 1.4 square miles with over 160 structures, but most are not in areas open to the public.  Even the areas that are open to the public have farms & residence in and among the sites.  As the site is not actually all that close to the Pacific ocean, it\'s probable that part of the site is on a salt dome, which was being harvested (and traded?) by the residents.

554633825.name: small mayan ruin without much to see
554633825.author: a TripAdvisor user
554633825.reviewBody: if you being to other major Mayan ruins in the Yucatans, this place can be skipped. Not really much to see for casual tourists

541126426.name: Interesting but Small Ruins
541126426.author: a TripAdvisor user
541126426.reviewBody: We did a quick tour of this small site along the roadway in Tapachula.  It is easy to locate and see the site as the main road in the area goes right past...the site is out in the open and can be hot in the direct sun, bug spray is also recommended.

485819391.name: A Look at Antiquity!
485819391.author: a TripAdvisor user
485819391.reviewBody: This is the pre-Hispanic Olmec and Mayan archeological ruins with buildings of restored and unrestored pyramids, and platforms of up to 60 feet high and covered two square miles at its peak. It is here where the calendars and esoteric spiritual beliefs were developed and taught. Izapa is considered the bridge between the Olmecs and the Mayans. A good day out for travellers who are interested in cultural history and archeology.

482488476.name: Tree of Life
482488476.author: a TripAdvisor user
482488476.reviewBody: Visited here as part of our tour from Puerto Chiapas. For some reason, the site of the ruins was not on the itinerary and we had to settle for a field where various stelae were mounted in crude shelters. The stelae are remarkable relics of an ancient civilisation but methinks they would be better housed in a small museum so that they can be studied and enjoyed by future generations. The Tree of Life, Stela 5, is regarded as the most important.

482460462.name: Mayan Ruins
482460462.author: a TripAdvisor user
482460462.reviewBody: Very interesting and not fully excavated 3000 year old Mayan Ruins. Probably will get the most out of this with a guide to fill some Mayan culture and history.

448329080.name: A Very well preserveded Mayan Ruin
448329080.author: a TripAdvisor user
448329080.reviewBody: The ruins were discovered by the farmer owning the land. He began plowing his. Field to plant corm. When he discovered uncovered the ruins, he stopped the plowing  and began uncover the ruins. It is a smaller version of the larger Mayan rulings but all the essentials items were present, with the pyramid, and the ball court and other buildings. The buildings were made by stacking rounded rocks without mortar . The y have now been secured with a mortar to secure further deterioration. I is a smaller site compared to the larger ones in Mexico, but good for taking your time to visit, explore and learn the history of the area. There were two groups there but well spaced and the visit was enjoyable  Be suree to take plenty  water during the hot season to prevent dehydration, as there is little shade at the site

445060164.name: Well kept archeological site, but very hot and not much shade!
445060164.author: a TripAdvisor user
445060164.reviewBody: We enrolled in this excursion while on our Panama cruise. The site was smaller than I had expected, since I hadn\'t ever been to one before. It was interesting but the heat of the sun had me seeking out the very limited shade available. \n\nI stayed in the bus when we went to the chocolate making demonstration, since I made a really dumb mistake the previous day when in the Guatemala port we stopped in at. I had a rum drink that obviously had ice made of regular water. That knocked me out of commission for a day. Something to really pay attention and not do!

439752828.name: Small site, loaded with history and stories
439752828.author: a TripAdvisor user
439752828.reviewBody: Learn about the ancient Olmec culture and their influence on the Mayans and the famous calendar which is believed to have been created in this area. This is great to do with a guide who will explain the purpose of each of the ruins and the civilization.

439446899.name: used guide to understand amazing ruins
439446899.author: a TripAdvisor user
439446899.reviewBody: We came here as part of a shore excursion from Puerto Chiapas.  The cruise terminal offers tours by the tour guides of Puerto Chiapas for $45 usd.  The Izapa ruins are part of that excursion.  Our tour guide explained the ruins very well and I recommend using a tour guide to understand what you are seeing.  These ruins are from about 1500 BCE and are only partially excavated.  You will need bug spray and a hat as well as sun screen when viewing this site.

435471523.name: Interesting for a short visit
435471523.author: a TripAdvisor user
435471523.reviewBody: We took in the ruins and the chocolate making demonstration in town on a half day tour.  The ruins were modest but still impressive.  The chocolate is quite different to what we are used to but very tasty indeed.  There is not much else to see in this area.

398184351.name: Izapa, the begining of cosmovision maya
398184351.author: a TripAdvisor user
398184351.reviewBody: This site is the oldest in Mayan culture, theres a man that has knowledge about the steles mayas and the means and history about olmecas and mayas cultures, Abelino Becerra had studied about the cosmovision of the mayans who lived on this site.

375004627.name: My guide made this experience memorable
375004627.author: a TripAdvisor user
375004627.reviewBody: I hired Cora Leslie a local guide and language teacher to take me around. Without Cora I wouldn\'t have had any idea what I was looking at. The ruins are closed on Tuesdays but Cora wrangled it so we got in and had the place to ourselves.\nYou can reach Cora on WhatsApp or mobile phone telephone +521 9621045499

363690817.name: Incredible Ruins !!!
363690817.author: a TripAdvisor user
363690817.reviewBody: Fascinating place.This site is mostly not excavated. It hasn\'t had any major excavations for several decades. Our guide was most knowledgeable and gave us a historical time table of the area and it significance. The is an exceptional place to visit.It is very  casual so you can go at your own pace and revisit some of the art facts as you wish.We were a small of of 12 and the only ones on the property at the time which made for a very intimate look into the past.

350154071.name: Amazing unspoilt place
350154071.author: a TripAdvisor user
350154071.reviewBody: We didn\'t come to these ruins but there is nowhere I can leave a review for the town of Tapachula .  Everything is in Mexican currency so don\'t think it\'s in US $.  You need to change your money as nowhere seemed to accept US$.  I got by because I speak some Spanish, but if you don\'t you may find the town daunting.  It\'s totally unspoilt and a lovely town full of hassle and bustle . If you want to see what Mexico is really like then take time to walk around the town and explore the back streets. We found it to be safe and fun because we went exploring. Some of my fellow travellers said they had beggars after them for money but our experience was great, no hassle and we found some fantastic souvenirs which were really inexpensive and it was fun to spend time here.  Wear comfortable shoes as the sidewalks are uneven in places.

347730500.name: Ruins are great
347730500.author: a TripAdvisor user
347730500.reviewBody: Was lucky to be there when there wasn\'t a cruise ship in town.  Very casual place with lots of information.  We weren\'t hounded by guides as at some other ruins. Be sure to go to all of the sites, they are spread out over a few miles on both sides of the road.

339470197.name: Fascinating Archeological Site
339470197.author: a TripAdvisor user
339470197.reviewBody: Although there are no doubt more fabulous Mayan ruins in Mexico, this site is fascinating in its own way and I would have loved, if I could have withstood the full blast of midday sun, to spend more time studying it in detail. We did have a most knowledgeable guide and I just wish I could remember even half of what he said as this seems to be a very important ruin. We had some people of the Mormon faith with us and apparently there is an item at the site that is of particular importance to Mormons and that is why they had come here. However if you come here, you must bring water and a hat as I didn\'t have either and I was absolutely wilting in the heat. I think there might have been a little store there to buy things but I didn\'t go into it so I\'m not sure what it does sell. In any case, I very much enjoyed this site and I wouldn\'t mind going back with a guide...but this time in winter.

339111221.name: Interesting small Mayan site
339111221.author: a TripAdvisor user
339111221.reviewBody: This site is mostly not excavated. It hasn\'t had any major excavations for several decades. Its significance culturally to the Mayans exceeds the relatively small scale of the site as it was perhaps the place from which the Mayan calendar was originally conceived. It is hot and in full sun here, so bring a hat and water. You will also need a good local guide or the ruins will mean little to you. It\'s probably the main attraction in this part of Chiapas, so worth a look if you have the time.

330665998.name: Stela 5 "Tree of Life" Stone
330665998.author: a TripAdvisor user
330665998.reviewBody: Travel time from the cruise pier to Izapa ruins will run about 45 minutes.  To our delight no entrance fees were collected.   The grounds are a large pre-Columbian archeological site whose beginnings can be traced back to around 1500 BC.  Originally just a very small village, Izapa grew into the region\u2019s most influential cultural and commercial center with a population of possibly up to 10,000 people at the height of its influence, sometime between 60 BC and AD 100. Once foremost in the region for the production of highly valued cacao, Izapa brought together many of Mesoamerica\u2019s ancient cultures and many believe it may be the site of origin of the sacred Mayan Calendar.  You will want to spend a minimum of 30 minutes here and then consider driving another 5 minutes to the lesser known Group A and Group B sites.  At the group A location will find Stela 5, known as the \u201cTree of Life\u201d stone.  Though not as grand as some of the other Mayan ruins, you will be pleasantly surprised with your visit.

278889383.name: Nice and historical Site!
278889383.author: a TripAdvisor user
278889383.reviewBody: Really nice archeological site, I went there because of a Personal reserch on Estela No.5 which is a fascinating sculptured standing stone with lot of history. I have reated this site 4 because you really need a guide there to lead you around, and it is very poor on information. I would recommend to visit only if you have a guide or someone who knows about mayan origins, history, regligion and more!

272797328.name: Very interesting...
272797328.author: a TripAdvisor user
272797328.reviewBody: While not as \'wow\' as Tulum, and some other ruins.  Was very interesting to see that this is only a small part of a larger Mayan area.  Worth a visit.  Take water.

257889567.name: Early Pyramids
257889567.author: a TripAdvisor user
257889567.reviewBody: Those interested in Mayan history or the history of Mexico will find this place fascinating. This pyramid and city are still in need of much more archeological digging.  The way the ancient Mayans used the sun, moon, and stars and aligned buildings and so on with these celestial skies is truly amazing.  It would be nice to return when more research has been done.

254607695.name: Very cool and trippy, not quite what you expect
254607695.author: a TripAdvisor user
254607695.reviewBody:
So just so you all know, there is not just ONE ruin site, but according to the local caretakers, there are 60 or 600 (my Spanish isn't that good), but I don't know where they all are, and our taxi driver was super nice, but not helpful at all with this.  Next time, we are going to have one of our friends that actually lives in Tapachula take us around as our tour guide.  We didn't realize there were so many different ruins you can go to.
Our taxi driver first took us to Grupo A, then we had to ask to go to Grupo B, and then finally we went to Grupo F, which I believe is the photo on this attraction listing.
Grupo F was the most well cared for of the sites, where the buildings aren't covered up.
Grupo A was not very interesting, just a mound where you could see some of the steps, but supposedly that one is the site where they made the Mayan calendar...you know the one that predicted the end of the world, but really it just predicted the end of the calendar.  There were some cool tablets they had set up, but most are pretty worn down and the signage is missing on quite a few that tells you what the tablet is all about.
I have to say Grupo B was my favorite, because there is just this HUGE mound of dirt, leaves, and rocks with trees growing on it, and underneath is a well buried temple.  I just kept tripping out on the whole thing, because there is was, totally hidden in plain sight, with little kids riding bikes on top of it.  If that was the United States, it would be fenced off, completely dug through, and they would be charging admission.
Here all you did was sign a guest book and walk wherever you wanted.
There is a lot more I could say, and some people who visit are probably totally disappointed, because there is not much going on at these places.  But I thought it was super cool, and a total trip, because I am from Los Angeles, and everything in L.A. is so polished and overdone, and here we were walking all over places that are pretty much left alone and waiting to be excavated.  I really like history, and seriously can't believe these places are still around and no one is exploiting them.  I can't wait to go back and see what else is around.
Bring a backpack with some snacks and water with you so you have time to really look around and take it all in.
Oh, I almost forgot, I saw that turtle head that is supposed to have magnetic powers, but I didn't have a compass or anything to test it out, that would be a cool thing to do.

254194749.name: Norwegian Cruise
254194749.author: a TripAdvisor user
254194749.reviewBody: Great spot, great views, pretty long ride there and back to the ship\n\nI would recommend it cuz there doesn\'t seem to be a lot to do here

244715571.name: Izapa Ruins from the NCL Star
244715571.author: a TripAdvisor user
244715571.reviewBody:
We visited the Izapa Ruins in Tapachula during a cruise stop in Puerto Chiapas during our cruise through the Panama Canal from Long Beach to Miami.      We were on the "Chiapas through the ages" tour from the NCL Star.  

The ruins were very crowded with tourists  and our bus load added to the crowd.  The ruins themselves were interesting, but not nearly as grand as some of the others we have seen.  Our guide was informative.   Unfortunately, these ruins are located adjacent to a small residential area and it seemed as if some of the ruins had been re-created.  I particularly enjoyed the location of the ballgame court.   All in all, it was still worth the visit.   

Definitely bring suntan lotion and bug spray and ensure you drink water.    Unfortunately with the ships tour, you will only have about an hour at the ruins.  It would have been nice to have an extra hour at this location.

243227764.name: Mayan History
243227764.author: a TripAdvisor user
243227764.reviewBody: We took a tour from our cruise ship to this historic Mayan Archaeological site.  The Izapa artifacts in the museum are something to see as we had never see ruins before.  The tour was not very long so you can take your time and see everything.  Afterwards you can venture into the small town of Tapachula and wander the town square.  A very nice tour.

240870731.name: Ruins and more!
240870731.author: a TripAdvisor user
240870731.reviewBody: Our guide, with Macaw Tours, Tapachula, was extremely knowledgeable and willing to take us wherever we wanted to go.  The ruins were at a small site - but there are more back into private land.  We also visited a woman\'s humble home, where she makes her own chocolate.  You wouldn\'t expect to see the pictures on the wall from when National Geographic came to sample her wares, and you wouldn\'t expect to see a certificate for first prize at an Italian Chocolate making competition - but they are there.  This woman showed us how to roast, shell, and grind the cacao, and it is hard work!  We will definitely use Macaw Tours, Tapachula again!!

237887074.name: Small Mayan ruins
237887074.author: a TripAdvisor user
237887074.reviewBody: If you haven\'t seen Mayan ruins, this is a good place to see them. It is a very small place and won\'t take very long to go through. Caution, do not take pity on little boys begging for money-give it to one then next thing you know, they are coming at you from everywhere.

224030430.name: Off the beaten path May Ruins
224030430.author: a TripAdvisor user
224030430.reviewBody: Not the most spectacular Ruins you will see.\nWe passed there on our road trip and made a stop as we were in the area.\nJust outside the city nice but nothing special if you have seen the big Maya Ruins

210311748.name: Fascinating Pre-Columbian, Olmec and Mayan Architectural site
210311748.author: a TripAdvisor user
210311748.reviewBody: Researchers believe that Izapa was first settled in about 1500 BC and was inhabited until around 1200 AD.  The ruins are located just outside the town of Tapachula in southern Mexico near the border of Guatemala at the foot of the Tacano volcano.  We visited the site as part of a shore excursion offered by our cruise ship and that is about the best way to get there from the Port of Chiapas.  Although not as large as some other sites it does have several pyramids, numerous carvings, a ball court which indicate a well developed, culturally developed society of inhabitants. Using a little imagination you can get a pretty  good idea of what life might have been like.

206815270.name: Puerto Chiapas-Izapa-Tapachula
206815270.author: a TripAdvisor user
206815270.reviewBody:
We arrived in Puerto chiapas on a cruiseship.If  you don't have a tour booked from the cruiseship,you have a few options once you get of the ship.
1-They offer you a tour of 45$ p person.
2-You can hire a taxi for the whole day,it costs 200$.These little vans can take 6/7 people,so if you have a small group that is possible to.
3-We walked out of the gate and at the end of the street(100 m)you see orange taxi's waiting.We talked to them and they said 100$for the whole day.Don't forget to ask if the taxi has airconditioning,since it is very hot!We are with 4 people,so this was the best choice.
We went to visit the Izapa ruins,the chocolate 'discovery' which takes place in a little town near Izapa next to the church and the main square where they demonstrate the process of chocolate making.You can taste different flavours but it tastes different then what we are used to.It is set up for the cruise ship tourists only.
There is great/free  WIFI in the M store in this same town.Just buy a cold coke and sit down in the airco!
Then you visit Tapachula.It is nice to walk around the main square,but in 1 hour max. you have seen it all.
At the end we also visited Playa Linda ,but it was deserted,very hot despite the hard wind and no shade.
Hopefully this information helps,it took me a lot of searching on the internet to find information with little result!

199653384.name: Pre-Columbian America\'s little-known gem
199653384.author: a TripAdvisor user
199653384.reviewBody: Izapa is lowland pre-Maya with many of the features of Mayan sites: pyramids, ball court, large plazas.  There are also many Olmec-influenced stela and stone carvings at a near-by location that is close to the main site.

199401331.name: Izapa Ruins Attraction
199401331.author: a TripAdvisor user
199401331.reviewBody: This is a small archeological site However, having said that it has pieces of archeologocial finds that leaves one as an observer wondering as to how this culture was able to sculpt large pieces of stone and the many symbols that were carved, what were they for?  It also helps you envision the landscape as to how houses or ceremonial areas may have been organized.  It is small site as I said.

197298869.name: One of many Mayan Sites
197298869.author: a TripAdvisor user
197298869.reviewBody: These ruins are believed to be the site of origin of the Sacred Mayan Calendar.  They are worth visiting but are not so impressive as other Mayan sites. Nicely kept and there is a knowledgeable guide who will take you around explaining the importance of the place.

188621264.name: Tapachula City and the Izapa Ruins, Puerto Chiapis Mexico
188621264.author: a TripAdvisor user
188621264.reviewBody:
Puerto Chiapis borders Guatemala and some cruise ships (Princess for sure) now stop there.  There has been a great deal of effort (and expense) made to develop a very nice cruise ship terminal area and the local people try very hard to make it a nice experience for cruise ship travelers.  There are two big (and I do mean big) Palapa terminal buildings.  

The main Palapa has several small shops, selling souvenirs (Amber, Silver, Jade jewelry - nice stuff; Coffee for $8 per bag, T-Shirts/clothes/bags).  It has large clean bathrooms and located next to them (on the wall) is a RED mailbox.  You can buy/mail your postcards from here.  Postcards sell here 3 for $2 USD and International stamps cost $1 USD each.  There’s also an Internet Cafe selling wi-fi at $3 for 20 minutes. 

The other Palapa has a restaurant/bar and a swimming pool. So if you don’t want to go to town, you can find things to do at the terminal for a few hours.

Cruise lines offer shore excursions but inside the main Palapa you can easily get shuttle transportation into Tapachula (and go on your own) or book a tour from the people selling them inside.  There is a tourist information booth that will offer you advice. Tapachula (meaning "Between the Waters”) is approx. 15 minutes away from the cruise port.  Don’t hesitate to go to Tapachula on your own, the people are nice.  Just keep in mind it is a small city and walking around to see the people and sights, will be your main entertainment.

We visited the House of Culture and the Soconusco Museum of Archeology in Tapachula where they have some artifacts that were originally found at Izapa.  It’s small (2 floors) and you can see most of it within 10 minutes but there are a few nice pieces; don’t miss the turquoise skull on the main floor. Washrooms are also located on the main floor.

Then we went to the Izapa ruins which is 10 Km away (approx. 20 minutes) from Tapachula.  The site is small (you can see it in under 1 hour) but worth a visit if you like visiting ruins.  The site has a variety of plants - fruit trees and flowers and a few local vendors selling souvenirs - handicrafts, nice carvings, chocolate, bottled water and coke/other soft drinks - for reasonable prices (bargain). There are washrooms on site (go to the yellow building near the main entrance) and some chairs set up near the front entrance, in case you get tired in the heat and want to rest.

184865374.name: Basic but historically interesting
184865374.author: a TripAdvisor user
184865374.reviewBody: The ruins are very basic but given the city was an extreme outpost of the Caribbean based Olmecs, its significance makes it a must-see in my mind. Admission is free and it\'s right on the highway to Talisman. It only takes 15 mins to walk the site so why not?!

181295582.name: Must visit
181295582.author: a TripAdvisor user
181295582.reviewBody: For someone interested in mayan culture this is a place of interest.  It is underdeveloped for tourism, but for the knowledgeable tourist is fine.

167793337.name: Nice diversion
167793337.author: a TripAdvisor user
167793337.reviewBody: I\'m hiking around the world, and came across this site as I walked down Highway 200. First off, the site\'s incredibly well maintained by the family that lives on site, who are wonderful and more than helpful I might add. As far as Mayan ruins go, it\'s hard for me to rate this high as a tourist attraction based on aesthetic appeal and the wonderful maintainers alone, as there simply I not much to it. Monika (another reviewer) mentions two sites, so maybe I missed out on the wider appeal, but comparing this to Tulum, Chitzen Itza, it\'s simply ok. And to jadeadvocate\'s point - the place is simply too small and is a nice to see, but the facilities and services offered are more than adequate considering the size and variety of what\'s here. If you\'re in the area, it\'s worth a stop over, but this place is definitely not worth going way out of your way for!\n\nOh one last thing... The dogs. Love Mitzi, but she wasn\'t fond of my backpack and lunged at me, good thing I had pants on, she might have taken skin. the dogs that guard the area are aggressive, so be careful with the kids.

161530090.name: Not for tourist boom but for deeper interest on the Maya
161530090.author: a TripAdvisor user
161530090.reviewBody: It takes you a while until you find your way to the Izapa Ruins, but you get rewarded for it, when you do not look for the big tourist glamour. Take time to go there and study first more about these ruins, than you will be satisfied. There are 2 different sites and both have their charm - mostly because you find yourself there almost alone.

160018077.name: the key to understanding the Mayas
160018077.author: a TripAdvisor user
160018077.reviewBody: The ruins are so important but there needs to be a visitors center and museum so thatvisitors understand what they are looking ay

157710839.name: Worth the visit
157710839.author: a TripAdvisor user
157710839.reviewBody: The ruins are located just outside of Tapachula on the way to the Tacan\u00e1 volcano.  They are right next to the highway but it is easy to miss them if you aren\'t paying attention. There are a few low profile monuments that you are allowed to walk on and take pictures of. There are also displays of various types of stone carvings. Definitely worth stooping on the way to visit some of the small towns on the volcano. Btw,  a half day trip to a few of the various towns on the volcano is also worth it. It is about 15 degrees cooler than Tapachula and there are lots of beautiful views.

148497228.name: Mexican Ruins
148497228.author: a TripAdvisor user
148497228.reviewBody: A rather enjoyable hour spent here. you are allowed to walk on the ruins and they have been kept well.

147877291.name: easy to get to and nicely kept --
147877291.author: a TripAdvisor user
147877291.reviewBody: these are two very impressive sites if you are a archeology buff.. If you are expecting tremendous structures rather than a park with slightly excavated structures you will be disappointed.. But if you want to see how the street and plazas line up South with Volcano Tacan\u00e1 -- and as a follow up to Tak\' Alik Ab \'Aj then it is very satisfactory...
